title.narrative: Output 1.1. Honduras: Relevant state actors have strengthened capacity and collaboration for integrated implementation of human rights and SDGs.

description.narrative: Capacity-strengthening activities conducted with the Secretaría de Coordinación General de Gobierno (SCGG), National Institute for Human Rights (CONADEH), Ministry of Human Rights (SEDH), National Bureau of Statistics, civil society networks, among others (at least 3 workshops / dialogues). Mapping document showing links between human rights obligations and SDG commitments; mapping of complaints against the SDGs; documentation of new structures and initiatives for integrated implementation, monitoring and reporting; published documentation on good practices.

title.narrative: Output 1.1. Honduras: Relevant state actors have strengthened capacity and collaboration for integrated implementation of human rights and SDGs.

description.narrative: Capacity-strengthening activities conducted with the Secretaría de Coordinación General de Gobierno (SCGG), National Institute for Human Rights (CONADEH), Ministry of Human Rights (SEDH), National Bureau of Statistics, civil society networks, among others (at least 3 workshops / dialogues). Mapping document showing links between human rights obligations and SDG commitments; mapping of complaints against the SDGs; documentation of new structures and initiatives for integrated implementation, monitoring and reporting; published documentation on good practices.

comment.narrative: Honduras has not linked its HR obligations to SDG implementation and monitoring. The government has committed to presenting its second VNR in 2020 and has just established a National Commission for the SDGs. Ministry of Human Rights and CONADEH are not systematically consulted or involved in SDG implementation and monitoring but are committed to advising the SCGG on the HRBA to the SDGs. Honduras is marked by severe human rights violations, including in the context of expansion of energy-related projects (SDG7), fisheries and resource-extraction. Ministry of Human Rights has committed to developing a National Action Plan on Business and HR with a focus on indigenous peoples (UPR recommendation), which can be linked to SDG implementation. CONADEH receive thousands of citizens’ complaints, but these are not linked to SDG monitoring/implementation. Civil society is broadly unaware of the SDGs and lack capacity to foster human rights implementation and accountability through the SDGs.

title.narrative: Output 1.2. Kenya: Relevant tools and analysis are developed, and capacity building and dialogue have taken place to facilitate improved coordination and collaboration between key state actors on a human rights-based approach to sustainable development.

description.narrative: Context-specific analysis and tools are available and used by key state and other actors , capacity is built among key state actors, and dialogue and joint activities between the KNCHR and state actors informed by the KNCHR’s data and analysis have been initiated; a policy paper on a HRBA to implementation of the current development plan is published; at least one training has taken place with targeted state and other actors; complaints to the KNCHR have been categorized and analysed through and SDG lens; at least one concrete direct collaboration between state actor(s) and the KNCHR has been established; and KNCHR has produced at least two monitoring reports that integrate an SDG lens to the recommendations provided to the State.

comment.narrative: Capacity building efforts and dialogue on human rights and sustainable development in Kenya currently limited to very few actors with a narrow focus. Ministry of Planning and Kenya National Human Rights Commission (KNCHR) are not currently engaged in active dialogue about human rights and SDGs. Context-specific tools and analysis to support an integrated approach to human rights and SDGs in Kenya are not yet available. KNCHR has a well-developed complaints-handling system, but it is not linked to SDG monitoring/implementation.

title.narrative: Output 1.3. Indonesia: Komnas HAM (the NHRI) has strengthened its capacity for promoting integrated implementation of human rights and SDGs and collaborate with relevant state actors for integrated implementation of human rights and SDGs.

description.narrative: Training of Komnas HAM staff; preliminary mapping of complaints against SDG goals and targets; published policy brief; Documented interaction between Komnas HAM, the SDG Secretariat of the Ministry of National Development Planning (BAPPENAS), the National Bureau of Statistics, and the Ministry of Law and Human Rights (at least 3 workshops or dialogues); Komnas HAM communications to regional SDG working group (at least 2).

comment.narrative: Involvement of human rights actors in SDG discussions is currently very limited in Indonesia. Komnas HAM is keen on bringing their human rights expertise into national SDG programming and review processes, and the authorities responsible for SDG coordination and implementation have shown interest in including Komnas HAM in these processes. Komnas HAM has limited experience on concrete work with the SDGs.
